title: I'll ALWAYS blow my top, admits Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger as he awaits punishment for shoving official
text:
Sport I'll ALWAYS blow my top, admits Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger as he awaits punishment for shoving official A touchline or even a stadium ban looms on Friday, although the 67-year-old hopes for leniency when the FA hear his explanation of last weekend's incident Share The Arsenal boss should learn on Friday how he'll be punished for pushing Anthony Taylor (Photo: REUTERS) Share     
Arsene Wenger admits he will never be able to control his temper on the touchline. 
Wenger is expected to discover his fate on Friday after accepting a Football Association misconduct charge after pushing fourth official Anthony Taylor during Arsenal ’s win over Burnley, but also requesting a personal hearing. 
The Gunners' boss will tell the FA he did not know he was not allowed to stay in the tunnel at the Emirates — where the incident occurred — after being sent from the pitch, and will plead for leniency following previous good behaviour in the last 12 months. But despite his public image as a mild-mannered professor-type, the 67-year-old Frenchman has confessed his temper has not mellowed with age. 
“I haven’t been touched by that yet,” said Wenger. 
“You do not make 34 years without interruption on the bench (as a manager) if you are not super-passionate. 
"I will put you in this job for six months and then we will talk again — if you are still alive. This isn't the first time Wenger has been in hot water over a touchline altercation (Photo: Daily Mirror) 
“I’ve been in England for 20 years, I have seen a lot on the bench, as you certainly know. I think if I am, after 34 years, still in the job it is because I am big enough to stand up for what I do. 
“And I’m big enough to know when I do well and when I do not do well. When I don’t behave like I think I should behave, I’m big enough say ‘Yes, that’s not right’, and that’s it.” 
Arsenal's Granit Xhaka is also in trouble — his red card in the Burnley game brings him a four-game ban and he has also been accused of racially abusing an airport worker at Heathrow. Losing banned Xhaka for four games led to an amazing claim from Wenger (Photo: Reuters) 
Wenger, who has jumped to the player’s defence over the latter incident, incredibly revealed he told the £35m midfield hardman to stop tackling because he cannot do it properly. 
“I would rather encourage him not to tackle, to stay on his feet and that’s the best way to deal with it," said the manager. "Tackling is a technique that you learn at a young age.
